title: Introduction to the mountainplot package
text: mountainplot package provide extension lattice package allows construction mountain plots, also known folded empirical cumulative distribution plots.

title: Introduction to the mountainplot package
text: Load package use singer data lattice package. Combine first second parts voice part new variable called section.
code: library("mountainplot") data(singer, package = "lattice") parts <- within(singer, { section <- voice.part section <- gsub(" 1", "", section) section <- gsub(" 2", "", section) section <- factor(section) }) # Change levels to logical ordering parts$section <- factor(parts$section,                         levels=c("Bass","Tenor","Alto","Soprano"))

title: Introduction to the mountainplot package
text: mountainplot, folded empirical cumulative distribution function, similar ordinary empirical CDF, cumulative probability reaches 0.50, CDF inverted, decreasing back instead continuing upward. example traditional empirical CDFs.  view data shown mountain plot.  Monti (1995) suggests mountain plot helpful exploring data makes easier : Determine median. Determine range. Determine central tail percentiles specified value. Observe outliers. Observe unusual gaps data. Examine data symmetry. Compare multiple distributions. Visually examine sample size. Additionally, area curve equal mean absolute deviation (MAD) Xue Titterington (2011).
code: require(latticeExtra) # for ecdfplot ## Loading required package: latticeExtra ## Loading required package: lattice ecdfplot(~height|section, data = parts, groups=voice.part, type='l',          layout=c(1,4),          main="Empirical CDF",          auto.key=list(columns=2), as.table=TRUE) mountainplot(~height|section, data = parts,              groups=voice.part, type='l',              layout=c(1,4),              main="Folded Empirical CDF",              auto.key=list(columns=4), as.table=TRUE)

title: Mountain Plots, Folded Empirical Cumulative Distribution Plots
code: require(mountainplot) data(singer, package = "lattice") parts <- within(singer, { section <- voice.part section <- gsub(" 1", "", section) section <- gsub(" 2", "", section) section <- factor(section) }) # Change levels to logical ordering parts$section <- factor(parts$section,                         levels=c("Bass","Tenor","Alto","Soprano")) mountainplot(~height|section, data = parts,              groups=voice.part, type='l',              layout=c(1,4),              main="Folded Empirical CDF",              auto.key=list(columns=4), as.table=TRUE)
